thread.title: 'We want a hard Brexit' - North East MP signs letter setting out demands to Theresa May

author: Jonathan Walker
title: 'We want a hard Brexit' - North East MP signs letter setting out demands to Theresa May
text:

Theresa May has been accused of being “too weak” to face down hard Brexiteers in her party, after 62 Conservative MPs set out their demands for the next stage of exit talks. 
Anne-Marie Trevelyan, MP for Berwick, was one of the Tories to sign a letter which insisted the UK should have the ability to change British rules and laws after Brexit - effectively ruling out continued membership of the single market or customs union. 
The letter also said the UK must be free to start its own trade negotiations immediately after Brexit, which in practice could prevent the UK continuing to be part of EU institutions during any transition period. Conservative MP for Berwick Anne-Marie Trevelyan 
Labour shadow Brexit minister Paul Blomfield said the letter showed Mrs May “is too weak to face down the fanatics in her own party and to deliver a final deal that protects jobs and the economy.” 
But some Conservatives pointed out that despite the tough language, the letter largely called for the Government to do what it has already promised anyway. 
It was drawn up by the European Research Group, a group of Tory Eurosceptics chaired by backbencher Jacob Rees-Mogg. 
Mrs Trevelyan is a member of the group. She also is a Parliamentary Private Secretary for Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, and it is unusual for someone in such a role to challenge Government policy. 
It seems the letter was never meant to be made public, but a copy was leaked to the Times newspaper. Mrs Trevelyan was not available for comment. Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: PA) 
Some Conservative MPs criticised the letter. 
Chelmsford MP Vicky Ford said: “Instead of helping the Prime Minister, it seeks to tie her hands. Read More Student tuition fees won't be abolished - so what WILL happen? 
“I do genuinely believe that some of the people who put their names to that letter didn’t fully understand the consequences it could have, particularly the limitations and restrictions they would have on an implementation period, making it much more difficult to have a smooth bridge between where we are today and towards that deep and special partnership.” 
Ministers last night attempted to head off a potential row with Eurosceptic MPs by insisting there will be a fixed end date for the post-Brexit transition period, during which Britain is expected to follow EU rules despite a leaked Government document which suggests it could last “indefinitely”. 
Brexit minister Steve Baker told BBC Two’s Daily Politics: “I’d be quite happy for us to have the minimum period necessary to get out successfully into the new arrangements but that is a matter to negotiate with the European Commission. Brexit Minister Steve Baker (Image: PA) 
“You can see that they want us to exit at the end of the budget period, the Prime Minister is suggesting two years. 
“But what will be the case is, when we’ve agreed, there will be a fixed date.” 
The transition period will begin after the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. Read More Jeremy Corbyn backs calls to get more women and girls into science and engineering 
Leaked documents suggested Government ministers want it to be determined by how long it takes the Government to introduce measures needed for life outside the union. 
The paper said this “points to a period of around two years”, but it does not set a firm end date. Like us on Facebook
